history.content:
You might have some luck with private tutors if you are willing to pay. I think the department has a list of tutors for the eecs lower division.

Otherwise, try going to office hours and HKN tutoring very early in the day/week so that it will be less crowded and you can get more individual attention. 

--------------------------------------------------

As a class, EE16A has great resources to build circuits intuition: Guerrilla sections, which occur on select Sundays, are designed to really build knowledge on key topics.   Vladimir's conceptual office hours on Tuesdays (after lecture) are fantastic too.  Ali Niknejad's circuits reader, linked on the course website, is a handy reference.   ...and so much more!

I suggest emailing a staff member -- we can design a plan to help you succeed in circuits!

You might have some luck with private tutors if you are willing to pay. I think the department has a list of tutors for the eecs lower division.

Otherwise, try going to office hours and HKN tutoring very early in the day/week so that it will be less crowded and you can get more individual attention. 

--------------------------------------------------

As a class, EE16A has great resources to build circuits intuition: Guerrilla sections, which occur on select Sundays, are designed to really build knowledge on key topics.   Vladimir's conceptual office hours on Tuesdays (after lecture) are fantastic too.  Ali Niknejad's circuits reader on the course website is a handy reference.   ...and so much more!

I suggest emailing a staff member -- we can design a plan to help you succeed in circuits!

You might have some luck with private tutors if you are willing to pay. I think the department has a list of tutors for the eecs lower division.

Otherwise, try going to office hours and HKN tutoring very early in the day/week so that it will be less crowded and you can get more individual attention.

In addition to what the above student suggested: 

You can try tutoring at the Center for Access to Engineering Excellence: http://engineering.berkeley.edu/student-services/academic-support/tutoring-schedule

Or try HKN: https://hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu/tutor/

You could also contact @Nicole Evans McIntyre  for the private tutor list if you are willing to pay for individual tutoring.

children.subject: Just as an additional offer to help, please also feel free to reach out to me to set up a time to meet and go over whichever concepts you feel unsure about. (I would have suggested my office hours, but they overlap with the 16A lecture, and I want to encourage everyone to attend lecture.). I'm obviously not teaching 16A this semester, but I'd be happy to help any 16A students with building up conceptual understanding.

history.content:
Hi! I'm currently a freshman in EE16A. I've already taken Math 54 so I found the linear algebra part of the course fairly easy, but I'm having a lot of trouble with circuits (I don't really have an extensive physics background and I don't understand most of the concepts). I know there are office hours and also drop-in tutoring from HKN, but are there any more structured tutoring sessions available? I really need someone to explain the concepts to me in more depth.

Thanks in advance!
history.subject: EE16A Tutoring?
